- Bb (if one gives B and the other gives b) In terms of the autosomal recessive condition, only those who have two copies (BB) would be affected. Bb individuals would be carriers but wouldn't have the disease yet. However, in reality, many autosomal recessive diseases require at least one copy to be expressed, meaning they're always carriers unless there's another factor. So why aren't any of their children showing the disease? Wait, but the question says neither Betsy nor Boopsy are anemic, which suggests they don't have the condition. So maybe the children don't display the condition because they're carriers, but carriers don't show the phenotype immediately—they just carry it. So perhaps the answer relates to whether the children are carriers or not. rollout:
Autosomal recessive means the heterozygote doesn't exhibit the disease, while the homozygotes do. So if Mr. Brown has one substitution in his beta-chain, he must have one Bb genotype. Similarly, Mrs. Brown has one substitution in her alpha-chain, so she also has one Bb. Therefore, their children would have a 50% chance of inheriting the B from Mr. Brown and the b from Mrs. Brown, resulting in Bb, which is a carrier. Since carriers don't show the disease, none of their children would be anemic, hence why they're not. But the question says neither Betsy nor Boopsy are anemic, implying that they don't have the condition. Wait, but the children might be carriers without displaying the disease. However, some textbooks suggest that autosomal recessive disorders require at least one copy to be expressed, so carriers would never show symptoms. So the key point is whether the children are carriers or not. Option G says the disorder can only be inherited from the mother. That seems incorrect because both parents contribute equally. Option C mentions that both children inherited a different form not detectable now. That's possible if the mutation isn't visible under normal conditions. Option F is a probability question, but the question is more about inheritance rather than probability. Option E says children can't be carriers because they're not anemic. No, because carriers don't show symptoms; they just carry the gene. So E is wrong. Option J says each child will inherit the disorder, but it remains dormant until adulthood. This aligns with the idea that some autosomal recessive traits take time to manifest after birth. Option H says neither parent can pass the disorder to their children, which is false because both parents can pass the B allele. Option A says only one parent can pass the disorder, which is incorrect because both can pass it. Option B says both parents will definitely pass it, which is true because they both have a single copy (Bb). Option D correctly states that both parents are heterozygous (Bb) and may or may not pass it to their children (the children could be Bb or BB). Option F is mixing probability with inheritance. Option G incorrectly claims the disorder is only inherited from the mother, which isn't accurate. So the correct answers are B, D, J.

The correct answer is B

Mr. Brown has one amino acid substitution in the \beta-chain of his hemoglobin molecules and Mrs. Brown has a similar defect in her \alpha-chain. Neither Betsy norBoopsy, their children, are anemic. Explain.

A. Only one parent can pass the disorder to the children

B. Both parents will definitely pass the disorder to their children

C. Both children inherited a different form of anemia that is not detectable at their current age.

D. Both parents have a homozygous trait but may or may not pass the disorder to their children

E. The children cannot be carriers since they are not anemic.

F. The children have a 50% chance of being carriers and a 25% chance of being affected.

G. The disorder can only be inherited from the mother.

H. Neither of the parents can pass the disorder to their children

I. The children are anemic but show no symptoms due to a modifier gene.

J. Each child will inherit the disorder, but it will remain dormant until adulthood.
